NATIONAL NEWS






Duke will ask for rate increase: If the state approves the utility's request, a typical household's power bill would jump $7.20 a month



May 31--Duke Energy, the state's largest electric utility, will seek to raise rates for the first time since 1991.  The Charlotte-based company announced Wednesday that it will ask the N.C. Utilities Commission for permission to raise residential rates by 6.8 percent, or $7.20 a month for the typical household. Industrial and commercial customers would see smaller changes.


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Nuclear reactor plan on hold: Promoting energy savings will come first, Progress Energy says. Expect rates to go up



May 31--Progress Energy will delay building a new reactor at the Shearon Harris nuclear plant in Wake County and instead push customers to use less electricity. Robert McGehee, chief executive of the Raleigh utility, said Wednesday that the company will also observe a moratorium on proposing coal-burning power plants as it devotes the next two years to testing whether its 1.2 million customers ...


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Referee forwards AEP-PSO rate case: Members of the Oklahoma Corporation Commission will review recommendations.



May 31--The referee overseeing the AEP-PSO rate case made many "point by point" recommendations to regulators Wednesday, but she did not determine whether electricity rates should increase or decrease, a spokesman with the Oklahoma Corporation Commission said.  Matt Skinner, a spokesman with the OCC, said the 164-page report submitted by Referee Jacqueline Miller would be turned over to ...


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Oregon electricity bills just got bigger



May 31--In an unusual and unusually brief session Wednesday, the Oregon Public Utility Commission approved one of the largest electricity rate increases in decades, one that will boost average home and small-farm bills by 13 percent. Utility rate hikes of any size normally require utility companies, consumer advocates and state regulators to haggle for months and exchange crates of ...


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Groups want Legislature to come back for electricity



May 31--Consumer groups are calling on Gov. Rick Perry to order the state Legislature back into session to make changes to Texas' competitive electricity markets.  AARP Texas and Texas ACORN, which advocates for low-income families, said a bill that died in the final hours of the legislative session on Monday fell short of making the kinds of changes they wanted to see, but would have been better ...


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



EPA panel gets an earful: Daylong hearing is held on state push to enforce tougher emissions rule.



May 31--California's much-vaunted law restricting greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles won't make a dent in global warming, even if adopted worldwide, a group of automobile manufacturers declared Wednesday.  Though delivered with bombshell flourish, the auto lobby's assertion at a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency hearing in Sacramento did not appear to rattle California representatives -- ...


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Two towns phasing out meter readers: Cary and Morrisville will buy self-reading meters that will eventually save money



May 31--CARY -- Town meter readers are facing looming obsolescence now that plans are in place to equip homes and businesses with self-reading machines. The new meters, slated to be installed in Cary and Morrisville over the next two years, will have wireless transmitters that Cary officials hope will beam readings to town hall no less than four times a day.


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Underground alternative: Some say Dane County power line should be buried



May 31--The quest to build a major power line across Dane County has shifted into a debate over whether the line should be buried or strung on giant towers above ground.  American Transmission Co. of Pewaukee wants to begin operating the line by 2013 to help the fast-growing Madison area keep up with rising demand for electricity. Concerns about the line prompted the mayor of Madison, the head of ...


May 31, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News





Cliffside estimate rises to $3,000/kW



-- Duke Energy Carolinas said it expects its proposed 800 MW Cliffside unit to cost $2.4 billion, including financing expenses, or $3,000/kW. Duke says it is 'reasonably confident' it will be able to keep the project costs to the current estimate. The company filed its latest estimate for the proposed unit with the North Carolina Utilities Commission. Duke says construction costs will be $1.8 ...


May 30, 2007 Power Engineering



Vectren ready to meet summer power demand



Evansville-based Vectren Energy Delivery told state regulators Thursday the company will have plenty of power to meet summer demand. The company issued its peak demand forecast for the summer months during the annual Energy Forum hosted by the Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission. Each of the state's large utilities discussed their forecasts and electric capacity with the commission this week. ...


May 31, 2007 Evansville Courier



Progress Energy defers nuke and pauses on coal



-- Progress Energy Carolinas said it has notified the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that if the company moves forward with plans for a new nuclear plant at the Harris site in Wake County, the new plant would be online in 2018 or beyond, at least two years later than initial energy demand forecasts had indicated. The company also said it would 'aggressively' implement energy-efficiency programs ...


May 30, 2007 Power Engineering



At windmills, dead birds, bats by the hundreds



ALBANY  While generating megawatts of electricity, windmills on the Tug Hill Plateau in northern New York are also killing hundreds of bats and birds, according to a recent study. The consultants report for PPM Energy and Horizon Energy identified 123 birds, mostly night migrants, and 326 bats found dead over the course of five months last year beneath 50 wind turbines on the plateau between Lake ...


May 31, 2007 Buffalo News



Green Equals Green At GE



-- GE recently reported that revenues from its portfolio of energy efficient and environmentally advantageous products and services exceeded $12 billion in 2006, up 20% from 2005, while the order backlog rose to $50 billion. 'Ecomagination is growing beyond our expectations, evolving into a sales initiative unlike any other I've seen in 25 years at GE,' said GE Chairman and CEO Jeff Immelt. ...


May 31, 2007 Industry Week



N.Y. electricity price drop slight when compared with other states



Deregulating New Yorks electricity markets has helped keep the states power prices from rising by less than the inflation rate over the last 12 years, a study commissioned by a group of energy services firms found Tuesday. The study found that residential electricity costs in New York dropped by 9.2 percent from their pre-deregulation peak in 1994 through last year, after adjusting for inflation. ...


May 30, 2007 Buffalo News



Power Authority shift spurs WNY hopes



Roger B. Kelley will lead the New York Power Authority. But new chief plays down area links The governing board of the State Power Authority hired an Amherst energy executive Tuesday as its chief operating officer. The hiring of Roger B. Kelley marks the first time a Western New Yorker will run the authority since the Niagara Power Project, one of the nations largest hydropower plants, was ...


May 30, 2007 Buffalo News



Utility gets approval to build towers across Livingston



Twenty-one miles of overhead power lines will be strung along 100-foot tall poles through eastern Livingston County, along M-59, to the General Motors Proving Ground in Milford. The Michigan Public Service Commission approved a certificate for construction of the power line to be built by Novi-based ITC Transmission. In addition, the commission plans to consider an extension of its underground ...


May 31, 2007 Detroit News



Airtricity opens 124 MW Forest Creek Wind Farm in West Texas



-- Airtricity North America has officially opened its 124 MW wind farm at Forest Creek, West Texas. The facility will generate enough electricity to power more than 35,000 homes and avoid the emission of 225,000 tons of greenhouse gases. TXU Wholesale will purchase the electricity generated by the wind farm, which entered commercial operation in March 2007.

Dominion to Streamline Corporate Structure by Merging CNG Subsidiary Into Holding Company



RICHMOND, Va., May 31 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Dominion (NYSE: D) announced today that it intends to merge its wholly owned subsidiary, Consolidated Natural Gas Company, into the parent holding company, Dominion Resources, Inc., as part of a move to streamline its corporate structure. The merger is targeted for the second to third quarter of the year. Dominion will then assume all obligations ...

Environmental Power Corporation Announces Intent to Dispose of Interest in Scrubgrass Generating Facility



EPC Reinforces Focus on Renewable Natural Gas and Carbon Market PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 31 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Environmental Power Corporation (Amex: EPG) announced today that its Board of Directors has unanimously authorized management to enter into negotiations finalizing the termination of the leasehold interest in the 83 megawatt waste coal-fired electric generating station located in ...


May 31, 2007 PR Newswire



'Stated Rate' Plan Pays Credits to PJM Members



PJM Interconnection is crediting refunds to its members as its rates continue to decline. A year ago, June 1, 2006, PJM instituted 'stated rates,' fixed rates to recover the costs to run the grid control organization. The rate plan included a five-year series of rate cuts. During 2007, PJM is crediting members' bills with a total of $6.5 million, or approximately one cent per megawatt-hour.

SEAL BEACH, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Clean Energy (NASDAQ:CLNE) today announced the closing of its initial public offering of 10,000,000 shares of its common stock at a price to the public of $12.00 per share. The net proceeds to the Company from this offering of approximately $108.8 million are expected to be used to build an LNG liquefaction plant and CNG and LNG fueling stations, to finance ...

Cheniere Energy Commits to Exercise 9,175,595 Share Call Options and Closes $400 Million Credit Facility



HOUSTON--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Cheniere Energy, Inc. (AMEX:LNG) announced today that it has notified Credit Suisse International (Credit Suisse) of Chenieres irrevocable commitment to exercise, on one or more occasions on or before July 23, 2007, all of Chenieres options to purchase from Credit Suisse an aggregate of 9,175,595 shares of Chenieres common stock for $35.42 per share.

Siemens to Provide Centerpoint Energy's Electric Transmission and Distribution Subsidiary Its First Flexible AC Transmission Systems



RALEIGH, N.C.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Siemens Power Transmission & Distribution, Inc. has been awarded a contract to provide CenterPoint Energy Houston Electric, LLC, a transmission and distribution subsidiary of CenterPoint Energy, Inc. (NYSE: CNP), with its first Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS). The turnkey contract for the FACTS projects will include all equipment and civil works for two ...


May 31, 2007 Business Wire



The Brattle Group Documents Significant Rate Increases in Both Restructured and Non-Restructured States and Recommends Strategies for Addressing Recent Rate Hikes



The Brattle Group has found that over the last decade, during which retail competition was introduced through restructuring of the electricity markets in 20 U.S. states and the District of Columbia, average electricity rates have increased 31% in both restructured and non-restructured states. The Brattle Group's working paper, Restructuring Revisited: What We Can Learn from Retail Rate Increases ...

Fitch Downgrades DQE's IDR to 'BB+'; Affirms Duquesne Light Company's IDR at 'BBB-'; Outlook Stable



NEW YORK--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Fitch Ratings has downgraded the Issuer Default Rating (IDR) and senior unsecured debt ratings of Duquesne Light Holdings, Inc. (DQE - formerly known as DQE, Inc.) to 'BB+' from 'BBB-'. FPL Energy files to build in Texas



A subsidiary of FPL Energy LLC has filed an application with Texas regulators to establish a new regulated utility business unit to construct, own and operate transmission facilities in Texas. The Juno Beach-based company said it has asked the Public Utility Commission of Texas (PUC) for a certificate of convenience and necessity for a unit to serve the Dallas/Fort Worth metroplex and other ...

Oregon Regulators Approve Rate Hikes for Some Smaller Electricity Users



- 12:22 a.m. PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) - The Oregon Public Utility Commission on Wednesday approved, reluctantly, a rate hike for some residential and small-farm electricity customers of private utilities in Oregon. The rate hike affects about 75 percent of electricity customers in Oregon. Portland General Electric and PacifiCorp customers will see a 13 percent hike in their bills beginning Friday, ...

Study: Competitive Electricity Markets Continue To Develop



The Alliance for Retail Choice (ARC) recently released a study showing that many states continue to make progress in adopting competitive retail electricity markets. New York and Texas were the clear leaders among states that have given customers the ability to choose their electricity supplier. "Our economy is built around competitive markets, and we need to bring the full advantages of that ...

California and Ontario agree to work together to combat warming



San Francisco (Platts)--30May2007 California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger and Ontario Premier Dalton McGuinty Wednesday signed a memorandum of understanding committing the state and province to work together to combat climate change. The two governments will explore potential linkages between regional market-based mechanisms, promote innovative technology and energy efficiency programs and ...


May 30, 2007 Platts



Entergy's Arkansas customers will see 12.6% hike



Entergy Corp. is adjusting rates for some of its residential customers in order to comply with a federal order. Entergy's customers in Arkansas face a 12.6 percent increase, while customers in Mississippi, Texas and part of Louisiana will get decreases ranging from 3.6 percent to 6.6 percent. New Orleans customers are unaffected, the company stated in a news release Wednesday.
